alert.note: Alert for Methow Valley; Okanogan Valley (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Spokane (Eastern Washington and Northern Idaho)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued July 16 at 2:34AM PDT until July 17 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane
info.description: ...DRY, BREEZY TO WINDY CONDITIONS SUNDAY AFTERNOON INTO MONDAY... .The breakdown of a hot ridge of high pressure and the arrival of a dry cold front will bring critical fire conditions to much of central and eastern Washington Sunday into Monday. Ahead of the front Sunday afternoon, hot south or southwest winds are expected to develop across central and north central Washington. Winds will shift to the west and northwest Sunday evening. On Monday, strong westerly winds will blow across central and eastern Washington in the wake of a dry cold front. ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 11 PM PDT MONDAY FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE METHOW AND OKANOGAN VALLEYS... * Affected Area: Fire Weather Zone 703 Okanogan Valley (Zone 703) and Fire Weather Zone 704 Methow Valley (Zone 704). * Winds: South-southwest 12 to 18 mph with local gusts to 30 mph late Sunday afternoon. Winds shifting to west and northwest Sunday evening. On Monday, west-northwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph. * Relative Humidities: 9 to 18 percent Sunday and 18 to 28 percent Monday. * Impacts: Hot southerly winds will develop in the Okanogan Valley this afternoon and become gusty after 2PM. Be cautious of shifting winds to the west Sunday evening. Winds in the Methow valley will start off light up-valley (southeast) today and increase from the west and northwest Sunday afternoon and evening. Temperatures near 100 Sunday afternoon combined with dry winds will lead to the potential for rapid spread of any new fires. Despite cooler temperatures and an increase in humidity Monday, strong wind are expected to blow through the day.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.
